Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.<RF>to…: Heb. to morrow day<Rf><CM>
Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.<CM>
A stone <FI>is<Fi> heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool's wrath <FI>is<Fi> heavier than them both.<RF>heavy: Heb. heaviness<Rf>
Wrath <FI>is<Fi> cruel, and anger <FI>is<Fi> outrageous; but who <FI>is<Fi> able to stand before envy?<RF>Wrath…: Heb. Wrath is cruelty, and anger an overflowing<Rf><RF>envy: or, jealousy?<Rf><CM>
Open rebuke <FI>is<Fi> better than secret love.
Faithful <FI>are<Fi> the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy <FI>are<Fi> deceitful.<RF>deceitful: or, earnest, or, frequent<Rf><CM>
The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.<RF>loatheth: Heb. treadeth under foot<Rf><CM>
As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so <FI>is<Fi> a man that wandereth from his place.<CM>
Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so <FI>doth<Fi> the sweetness of a man's friend by hearty counsel.<RF>by…: Heb. from the counsel of the soul<Rf>

Thine own friend, and thy father's friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother's house in the day of thy calamity: <FI>for<Fi> better <FI>is<Fi> a neighbour <FI>that is<Fi> near than a brother far off.<CM>
My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.<CM>
A prudent <FI>man<Fi> foreseeth the evil, <FI>and<Fi> hideth himself; <FI>but<Fi> the simple pass on, <FI>and<Fi> are punished.<CM>
Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.<CM>
He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.<CM>
A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, <FI>which<Fi> bewrayeth <FI>itself<Fi>.<CM>
Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.<CM>
Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.<CM>
As in water face <FI>answereth<Fi> to face, so the heart of man to man.<CM>
Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.<RF>never: Heb. not<Rf><CM>
<FI>As<Fi> the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so <FI>is<Fi> a man to his praise.<CM>
Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, <FI>yet<Fi> will not his foolishness depart from him.<CM>
Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, <FI>and<Fi> look well to thy herds.<RF>look…: Heb. set thy heart<Rf>
For riches <FI>are<Fi> not for ever: and doth the crown <FI>endure<Fi> to every generation?<RF>riches: Heb. strength<Rf><RF>to…: Heb. to generation and generation?<Rf>
The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
The lambs <FI>are<Fi> for thy clothing, and the goats <FI>are<Fi> the price of the field.
And <FI>thou shalt have<Fi> goats' milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and <FI>for<Fi> the maintenance for thy maidens.<RF>maintenance: Heb. life<Rf><CM>
